intro: Whitia pilosa, commonly known as the hairy mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees. It has small, oval-shaped leaves that are covered in fine, hairy structures, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers that are typically clustered in dense inflorescences. Its berries are usually red or yellow and contain seeds that are dispersed by birds. Whitia pilosa is found in various parts of Africa and is adapted to thrive in shaded, forested environments.
